value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">8</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">ourselves. The chairs and tables are there; but the</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><rs type="place" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#pla-wilt">Wilton</rs> <rs type="place" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#pla-pens">Penshurst</rs>, <rs type="place" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#pla-hard">Hardwick</rs> all are untenanted.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Only the furniture remains-- the lacquered, the</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">highly painted, the ornate, the 
            <choice>
              <sic>conv luted</sic>
              <corr>convoluted</corr>
            </choice>; the chairs and</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">tables that must have been so so hard to sit upon;</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">If they were like their furniture, they were</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">at once ceremonious; and crude; fantastic yet sharp,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">pointed, uncushioned;</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">The writer <del hand="ms">who</del> hesitated conscious of his 
            <choice>
              <sic>pelebian</sic>
              <corr>plebian</corr>
            </choice></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>bith</sic>
              <corr>birth</corr>
            </choice> on the threshold of the great roo, <add hand="ms" place="above>">, he</add> was still 
            <choice>
              <sic>unspeciali</sic>
              <corr>unspecialised</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">undifferentiated. His eye was stimulated <del hand="ms">;</del> by the crimsons and</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the golds and the greens of the 
            <choice>
              <sic>lothing</sic>
              <corr>clothing</corr>
            </choice>; by the angles and</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">patterns on the 
            <choice>
              <sic>ceilinsg</sic>
              <corr>ceilings</corr>
            </choice>; His ear <del hand="ms">too</del> was stimulated and</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>peicked</sic>
              <corr>pricked</corr>
            </choice> <add hand="ms" place="above">by [words?]</add>. Books were 
            <choice>
              <sic>rea</sic>
              <corr>read</corr>
            </choice> aloud; each word was given sharpness</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">and 
            <choice>
              <sic>subatnce</sic>
              <corr>substance</corr>
            </choice> by the speaking voice. And then when the lord</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">or lady took his lute and sang, lilt, 
            <choice>
              <sic>rhytm</sic>
              <corr>rhythm</corr>
            </choice>, melody was 
            <choice>
              <sic>addd</sic>
              <corr>added</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">to the substance and sharpness of the words. Words bubbled</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">in his mind, old words, English words, 
            <choice>
              <sic> rech</sic>
              <corr>French</corr>
            </choice> words, 
            <choice>
              <sic>Ladtin</sic>
              <corr>Latin</corr>
            </choice></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">words. They were 
            <choice>
              <sic>motlen</sic>
              <corr>molten</corr>
            </choice>, capable of taking any shape, of</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">reflecting 
            <choice>
              <sic>nay coloure</sic>
              <corr>any colours</corr>
            </choice>, of 
            <choice>
              <sic>folliwng</sic>
              <corr>following</corr>
            </choice> the ones, of taking the</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>rhymn</sic>
              <corr>rhythm</corr>
            </choice> of the 
            <choice>
              <sic>l te</sic>
              <corr>lute</corr>
            </choice>. No grammar bound them tightly; nor did</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">one society inflict its canons of good taste.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Whether he 
            <choice>
              <sic>ws</sic>
              <corr>was</corr>
            </choice> to write or to sing or to paint was an open</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>uetion</sic>
              <corr>question</corr>
            </choice>. The arts were closely interwoven. For a moment</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">there is a pause on the threshold of the great 
            <choice>
              <sic> l zabethan</sic>
              <corr>Elizabethan</corr>
            </choice></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">house, when the artist sees 
            <choice>
              <sic>begore</sic>
              <corr>before</corr>
            </choice> <add hand="ms" place="above">[illeg.]</add> him three different paths.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Shall he sing, or paint, or make poems? And then there</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">rose up from the 
            <choice>
              <sic>couryard</sic>
              <corr>courtyard</corr>
            </choice> the crude <add hand="ms" place="above">[voices?]</add> tones of the mummers.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">It was the stagethat settled it. Had there been no stage,</l>
